Description: Mould-made amuletic figure in glazed composition, representing Harpokrates; represented as naked male child, standing; wearing the sidelock of youth to the right side of his head; right arm bent to hold his hand to his mouth; holding below his left arm a tubular object, likely a pot (honey pot?); three small protruding elements on his head (lotus buds?); rather fine modelling, with marked belly button; rather dark green thick glaze; white fine core; lower legs missing; faience chipped in places; head broken and glued back.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Musée du Louvre. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Findspot of Naukratis in Louvre register. Studies by Kaczmarczyk in 1982; listing by Kaczmarczk 1985: LRMF no. 10546 (Green back of a Harpocrates Figurine, Naukratis, Roman Egypt: Fe 1.4, Cu 2.9, Pb 7.7, Sn 0.5, Sb 2.6)

The child deity was very popular in Naukratis. He appears in a large number of small votives and amuletic figures, in a variety of materials and shapes (Masson forthcoming). His cult was particularly developed in the Delta during the Late and Ptolemaic periods (Sandri 2006). On Harpokrates (or child god) amulets see: Andrews 1994, 16, fig. 10; Herrmann et al. 2010, 28-29 (type 2). On this figurine, see recently: Kaczmarczyk, Nenna 2014, 309-10, fig. 4.
